title: Calculate Water Quantity in a Room

data.title: Calculate Water Quantity in a Room
data.solution:
# Get dimensions
length, width, height = [int(i) for i in input().split()]

# Check if all dimensions are greater than zero
if all(dim > 0 for dim in [length, width, height]):
    volume = length * width * height
    print(f"The quantity of water in the room is {volume} cubic feet.")
else:
    print('Invalid dimension')
data.statement:
You have a room filled with water, and you need to calculate the quantity of water in cubic feet that the room contains. You are given the dimensions of the room: length, width, and height in feet.

Takes the room's dimensions as input and calculates the volume of water in the room. If any of the room's dimensions are zero or negative, output {{Invalid dimension}}.

testCases.title: Test 1
testCases.testOut: The quantity of water in the room is 9000 cubic feet.

testCases.title: Validator 1
testCases.testOut: The quantity of water in the room is 1000 cubic feet.

testCases.title: Validator 2
testCases.testOut: The quantity of water in the room is 960 cubic feet.

testCases.title: Test 3
testCases.testOut: The quantity of water in the room is 60 cubic feet.

testCases.title: Test 4
testCases.testOut: The quantity of water in the room is 42 cubic feet.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

You have a room filled with water, and you need to calculate the quantity of water in cubic feet that the room contains. You are given the dimensions of the room: length, width, and height in feet.

Takes the room's dimensions as input and calculates the volume of water in the room. If any of the room's dimensions are zero or negative, output Invalid dimension.
Input
Three integers separated by spaces, representing the length, width, and height of the room in feet.
Output
Either The quantity of water in the room is volume cubic feet., where volume is the volume of water in the room, or Invalid dimension.
Constraints
Example
Input
25 18 20
Output
The quantity of water in the room is 9000 cubic feet.
